properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is occurring, and is expected to change over to snow this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds will develop tonight with gusts over 90 km/h. Winds are expected to remain strong over most areas on Saturday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain, and wind is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 15 to 30 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except locally 100 km/h. Locations: Bay D'Espoir, Burin and Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: Sunday morning through to Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning before changing to rain Sunday afternoon. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop Sunday. Rain combined with mild temperatures has the potential to cause localized flooding, especially given the large existing snow pack. There remains some uncertainty regarding total precipitation amounts and the public is advised to monitor future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and wind expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h . Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday morning through to Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning in the southwest and will spread to the north by Sunday afternoon. Current indications have snowfall accumulations of near 10 cm by the time the snow tapers to flurries Sunday night, but locally higher amounts are possible. The public is advised to monitor future forecasts for updates on this system. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Damaging westerly winds with gusts to 130 km/h this morning will slowly weaken throughout the day. Winds are expected to be below warning criteria by noon in most regions, but will last until this afternoon in areas around Lethbridge. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and wind expected. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h with possibly gusts to 100 km/h. Locations: southeastern coastal Labrador. Time span: Sunday night through to overnight Monday. Remarks: Snow, strong north to northwesterly winds, and blowing snow are expected to develop Sunday night. Visibility will likely be near zero in blowing snow along exposed areas of the coast. Snow is expected to diminish to flurries by Monday evening but the strong winds will likely continue into Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. An intense low pressure system with subtropical moisture has brought heavy rain to most of the south coast since Thursday night. Parts of the south coast regions have received 120 to 140 mm of rain during the last 24 hours. Heavy rain will continue this morning as the cold front associated with the system crosses the south coast. The rain will taper off this morning as the system departs the region. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T04:07:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T12:08:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4026393928.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Locations: Burgeo and northward to Green Bay - White Bay. Time span: Sunday morning until Sunday evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is expected to begin Sunday morning. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm are expected before the snow tapers to flurries Sunday evening. Winds are expected to increase throughout the day with northeasterly gusts up to 70 km/h by Sunday afternoon. The fresh snow combined with strong winds will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow on Sunday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T06:21:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T14:22:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4148221665.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter are high in the Greater Montreal Area and will remain so today and possibly on Sunday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-02T15:44:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-02-01T09:45:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0969525905.2020
Area: Saint-Jérôme area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Longueuil - Varennes area, Laval area, Montréal Island area, Châteauguay - La Prairie area, Soulanges area, Vaudreuil area, Saint-Rémi area, Valleyfield - Beauharnois area, Hemmingford area, Huntingdon area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area, Sorel - Yamaska area, Saint-Hyacinthe - Acton Vale area, Verchères - Beloeil area, Saint-Jean - Marieville area, Lacolle area

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Weekend snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, but potentially approaching 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 60 km/h possible. Locations: eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: late this afternoon to early Sunday morning. Remarks: A developing storm over the Atlantic Ocean will affect parts of Nova Scotia tonight. Snow is forecast to spread across the southern half of the province this afternoon, with most of the accumulation over central regions expected tonight. Snowfall warnings have been issued for Antigonish County, Guysborough County, and Cape Breton, but the latest forecast guidance continues to indicate lesser snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm further to the west. However, there is still some uncertainty in the track of this system, and a shift to the northwest could increase snowfall amounts over central Nova Scotia. The forecast will be updated as the system approaches. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T00:56:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T08:57:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3392240285.2020
Area: Colchester County North, Colchester County - Truro and south, Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Pictou County

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Weekend snowfall. Total snowfall: near 15 for the eastern mainland and 15 to 25 cm for Cape Breton. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 70 km/h. Locations: eastern mainland and Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Sunday. Remarks: A developing storm over the Atlantic Ocean will spread snow across eastern Nova Scotia this evening. The greatest snowfall accumulations are expected over Guysborough, Richmond, Sydney, and Victoria counties. Rain will likely mix with the snow along the Atlantic coast before the precipitation ends from west to east during the day on Sunday. In addition, there is a risk of freezing rain further inland early on Sunday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T00:57:13-00:00

Area: Guysborough County, Antigonish County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. Concentrations of fine particulate matter will increase again today and may remain high through Sunday. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-02-02T15:48:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-02-01T09:49:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2040558583.2020
Area: Louiseville area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-Pérade area, Trois-Rivières area, Bécancour - Villeroy area, Victoriaville area, Nicolet area, Drummondville area, Granby - Waterloo area, Brome-Missisquoi area, Richmond area, Weedon area, Thetford Mines area, Mont-Orford - Lake Memphrémagog area, Sherbrooke area, Coaticook area, Lac-Mégantic area, Cookshire area

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 100 km/h along the coast. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Sunday afternoon and evening. Remarks: Southeasterly winds are expected to increase throughout the day on Sunday with gusts reaching up to 100 km/h along the coast by Sunday afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-02-02T06:21:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T14:22:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1254047099.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are occurring along the Icefields Parkway. A long duration heavy snowfall event is occurring and is expected to end Saturday evening. Another 10-20 cm of snow is expected today. Total snowfall amounts will be between 30 and 50 cm, with locally upwards of 70 cm possible. Strong winds will accompany the snow, which will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow at times, especially over exposed areas. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-02T03:48:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T11:49:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2273586406.2020
Area: Highway 93 South - Lake Louise to Saskatchewan River Crossing, Highway 93 North - Jasper to Saskatchewan River Crossing
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An intense low pressure system over the North Coast is bringing southwest winds of 90 km/h to sections of the central coast this evening. Winds will veer and ease to northwest 50 to 70 km/h in the wake of the low after midnight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-02-01T15:14:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-02-01T06:34:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3049598010.2020
Area: Central Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada
